docs.abstract: The Feb. 16 episode of “The Ezra Klein Show.”
docs.snippet: The Feb. 16 episode of “The Ezra Klein Show.”
docs.lead_paragraph: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode about the cost of racism with Heather McGhee. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.

headline.main: Transcript: Ezra Klein Interviews Heather McGhee about the Cost of Racism

docs.abstract: Our country has struggled to reckon with the horrors of the past. Could DNA tests help?
docs.snippet: Our country has struggled to reckon with the horrors of the past. Could DNA tests help?
docs.lead_paragraph: The consumer genetics testing company 23andMe this month announced that it is going public through a merger with a company founded by the billionaire Richard Branson, in a deal that valued it at $3.5 billion. This was just the latest big deal for the industry: Last year, the Blackstone Group acquired a majority stake in Ancestry, a 23andMe competitor, for $4.7 billion.

headline.main: America’s Brutal Racial History Is Written All Over Our Genes
headline.print_headline: Our Racial History Is Written All Over Our Genes

docs.abstract: Wednesday: A look at one city’s effort to remake policing. Also: Xavier Becerra’s confirmation hearings; and remembering Lawrence Ferlinghetti.
docs.snippet: Wednesday: A look at one city’s effort to remake policing. Also: Xavier Becerra’s confirmation hearings; and remembering Lawrence Ferlinghetti.

headline.main: Berkeley Moves Closer to Ending Police Traffic Stops

docs.abstract: After a tumultuous year and the end of a presidency, voters say that Donald J. Trump’s second impeachment feels very different from his first.
docs.snippet: After a tumultuous year and the end of a presidency, voters say that Donald J. Trump’s second impeachment feels very different from his first.
docs.lead_paragraph: It has been just over a year since former President Donald J. Trump first faced impeachment charges in the Senate, but it feels like a decade.

headline.main: A Shared Sense of Alarm: Here’s What Americans Said About Two Impeachments
headline.print_headline: Trump’s Second Impeachment, in a Word

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: Trump-Ukraine Whistle-blower Complaint and Impeachment Inquiry

byline.original: By Rick Rojas, Will Wright, Giulia McDonnell Nieto del Rio, Lucy Tompkins and Jake Frankenfield

docs.abstract: While her daughter was hospitalized, one mother built more room for our national grief.
docs.snippet: While her daughter was hospitalized, one mother built more room for our national grief.
docs.lead_paragraph: Strapped in the front seat of an ambulance as her daughter lay injured in the back, Kaye Steinsapir took out her phone and began to type.

docs.abstract: For incarcerated people like me, access to communications comes at a steep price.
docs.snippet: For incarcerated people like me, access to communications comes at a steep price.
docs.lead_paragraph: Mom will probably die before I get out of prison. Her Parkinson’s has advanced over the years, so she can’t visit. Until recently, I’d accepted that I’d never see her again. But lately, she’s been sending me 30-second videos: Mom and Magic, her fat, one-eyed black cat, showing me love through the seven-inch screen of a tablet made by a service provider called JPay. It costs her about a dollar to send each message; to me, they are priceless.

headline.main: The Cost of Calling My Mom From Prison

docs.abstract: A federal court ruling moves New York City closer to releasing a vast trove of records regarding police misconduct, a major milestone in a decades-long fight.
docs.snippet: A federal court ruling moves New York City closer to releasing a vast trove of records regarding police misconduct, a major milestone in a decades-long fight.
docs.lead_paragraph: A federal appeals court in New York cleared the way on Tuesday for the city to release hundreds of thousands of police disciplinary records, a major milestone in a long and bitter political battle to open the records to public scrutiny.

headline.main: Police Unions Lose Bid to Keep Disciplinary Records a Secret
headline.print_headline: Discipline Records of New York Police Near Release

docs.abstract: Mayor Jesse Warren’s landlord happens to be one of his predecessors. He says a political rivalry is the reason he’s getting kicked out.
docs.snippet: Mayor Jesse Warren’s landlord happens to be one of his predecessors. He says a political rivalry is the reason he’s getting kicked out.
docs.lead_paragraph: In one of the Hamptons’ most elite enclaves, amid shingle-style mansions and beachfront estates, a man has been living without authorization in a two-bedroom apartment in a house on David Whites Lane. His lease expired months ago. His latest rent check has gone uncashed.

headline.main: Is the Mayor of an Exclusive Hamptons Enclave a Squatter? It’s Complicated
headline.print_headline: Beaches, Estates and a Mayor’s Eviction Battle

docs.abstract: “I gotta say, Orlando is awesome,” he said while opening his speech. “It’s not as nice as Cancún — but it’s nice!”
docs.snippet: “I gotta say, Orlando is awesome,” he said while opening his speech. “It’s not as nice as Cancún — but it’s nice!”
docs.lead_paragraph: ORLANDO, Fla. — Senator Ted Cruz has decided to own it.

headline.main: Ted Cruz, speaking at CPAC, jokes about his Cancún trip and tells media to ‘lighten up.’

docs.abstract: The evocative podcast about people who “refuse to accept things as they are” is thriving in a historical blind spot of story-driven audio.
docs.snippet: The evocative podcast about people who “refuse to accept things as they are” is thriving in a historical blind spot of story-driven audio.
docs.lead_paragraph: In late 2018, Saidu Tejan-Thomas Jr. (pronounced “sai-eed”) heard something he couldn’t get out of his head.

headline.main: Saidu Tejan-Thomas Jr. and the Voices of ‘Resistance’
